She says that the group "taught her how to share responsibility." "The women help each other with their problems, and that way we all come out ahead together."

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Doña Maria Pabla K. de Medina, es una señora de 47 años. Es antigua moradora de Pelopincho, el más grande de los barrios marginales de Asunción. Se la ve fuerte y sana, pero aparenta más edad de la que tiene. Doña Pabla es vendedora ambulante de cosméticos y ropas que trae de Clorinda, una ciudad argentina en la frontera cercana a Asunción. Por la noche, sube al centro de la ciudad y recicla cartones. Ambas actividades le proporcionan un ingreso de 40 dólares semanales con lo que mantiene a dos de sus seis hijos y ayuda a los mayores, que a su vez tienen hijos pequeños. Desde el año pasado forma parte del comité “Tekoyeyoyá”, junto a otras 14 vecinas y amigas del barrio. Doña Pabla cuenta con tristeza que tuvo que separarse de su marido porque “era borracho y no tenía trabajo” y “cuando tomaba bebida alcohólica, se ponía como loco”. Hace nueve años que lo dejó y para ella es como si su marido hubiera muerto. Desde entonces asumió ella sola la crianza de sus hijos. Asegura con orgullo que nunca permitió que sus hijos pidieran limosna en las calles y tampoco permite que lo hagan sus nietos. “Le pido a Dios que me de fuerzas para seguir luchando”, dice emocionada, con lágrimas en los ojos, porque quiere lo mejor para su familia y para su comunidad. Del grupo “aprendí lo que es la responsabilidad con los demás”, nos cuenta. “Todas las señoras nos ayudamos en nuestros problemas y así salimos adelante todos juntos”.

loans.use: To buy a case of nail polish and hand cream.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
Elvira G. is 32 years old and has 3 children, ages 14, 12, and 2. She helps her mother, 74, run her small grocery store located at their house. They sell products such as wine, beer, pasta, bread, and household products. Most of the customers are neighbours. Elvira’s children also help out with the store. They started this business over 20 years ago.

Aside from the small store, Elvira also sells chipas, a type of cornbread street snack. Elvira only makes and sells the chipas on Sundays and at soccer games. Elvira is requesting a $250 loan to resupply her store and buy more products such as beer, which is the highest demanded product.

Elvira is member of a committee of women. This group lending allows members to guarantee a loan through a group repayment pledge. The incentive to repay is based on peer pressure; if one person in the group fails to repay their loan, the other group members make up the payment amount.

loans.use: Purchase beer and wine.

loans.name: Vurgun

texts.en: Vurgun is 27 years old, single and lives in the Yenikand village of the Salyan region. He has 3 years of experience in this buisness. Now this young  man needs a loan of $475 to buy a plot of land to open an Orchard farm. of his own.

loans.use: To buy a plot of land

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en:
Vilma belongs to the village bank Las Palmeras, Spanish for ‘The Palm Trees’. She has two grown children and five grandchildren that she helps care for. Up until about five years ago Vilma had a restaurant in Lima, but she had to leave this work when her landlord sold the building due to a major rent increase. She then opened a small stand that is very popular with the women of her neighborhood. Vilma runs a ‘ropa interior’ stand, selling everything from socks and underwear to nylons and nightgowns.

Vilma's daughter recommended that she join her village bank, and now Vilma is grateful to belong to it. She says belonging to Las Palmeras has inspired her and given her a new work ethic, a dedication to do well for herself. Vilma will use this loan of $100 to expand the variety of the ‘ropa interior’ that she sells, so she can satisfy the growing requests of her customers.

loans.use: expand the variety of the ‘ropa interior’ she sells

loans.name: Ordaliza Lima

texts.en:
Ordaliza is a very young entrepreneur and mother of two girls (ages 8 and 2) and a 6-year-old boy. Contrary to the great majority of women here, Ordaliza says the fact of being a mother won’t impede her in continuing her studies. Twice a week, she goes to Santo Domingo to attend classes at the university.

Ordaliza sells vegetables, spices, and ripe fruit. Her stall is always very crowded, and people who visit her once always want to come back because of her wisdom and empathy. She says she sells for more than 1000 Dominican pesos daily (about US$ 30).

The entrepreneur is requesting a loan to purchase more goods to offer to her clientele and so that she can attract new customers. In the past, Ordaliza has proved to be an honest, reliable person. She had already taken a loan from FSMA and was able to repay it without problem.

loans.use: To invest in the purchase of vegetables and fruits to supply her small business

loans.name: Sara

texts.en:
Hello from Mbeya, Tanzania! Sara M. is a 49 year old woman who is married with four children, who are between 18 and 23 years of age. In 2000 Sara established a farming business. She now requires a loan of $200 in order to purchase seeds, fertilizer, and tools. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA


SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania, where customs and traditions normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets. Because they lack tangible collateral assets, women are considered not creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low income.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro Leasing as a practical way to achieve economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA buys equipment and leases it to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from her, extending her a loan, and then leases the same equipment back to her – a process called "sale and leaseback".

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers, and tools for farming

loans.name: Tiira Road B Group

texts.en: The leader of this small group is Agnes M..  She is currently in the business of selling yellow bananas and is requesting a loan to expand the business.  Agnes is 33 years old and married. Her husband is a businessman.  She has 4 children ranging from age 5 to 15, and her children go to school.  Each week, Agnes makes approximately UGX 100000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to help her husband complete the house they are constructing.  Agnes previously had a loan from BRAC Uganda in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to invest in her business, and the loan was paid back on time.  Agnes is joined in her group by Lucy A., Grace W. and Lydia N..  Lucy A. has a business in fruit and vegetable sales and wants to increase stock.  Grace W. is currently operating a business in matooke sales and wants a loan to purchase additional matooke for sale. Lydia N. also sells matooke and wants to use the loan to purchase more matooke from nearby villages.

loans.use: To  expand banana business

loans.name: Santina

texts.en:
Santina is 32 years old and is a single woman. Santina has a food store that she started in 2007. Every day, she works from 6am to 7pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $30 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is 41 years old and is a married woman with 4 children, ages 18,15,10 and 7 years old. Amina owns a small shop, which she started in 2006. Everyday, she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $225 from her sales.

In the past, Amina has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Winnie's Furaha Group

texts.en:
Winnie is 32 years old and is a married woman with 3 children, ages 18,14 and 4 years old. Winnie owns a small general store, which she started in 2000. Every day, she works from 8 a.m. to 9 p.m. at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $225 from her sales.

In the past, Winnie has taken out 1 successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Triza, Mary and Miriam, who have businesses dealing in timber sales, clothing sales and crops sales.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Angela

texts.en:
Angela O. is a fashion designer and she also sells clothes in Okoko, Lagos State, Nigeria. She has 5 machines and 2 apprentices. She learned this skill over a 3-year period and has been in her business since 2000. She is 36 years old and is married with 4 children.

Angela has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past 4 years. She now needs a loan of $850 to buy more tailoring materials and two additional sewing machines. With this expansion she will be able to render better serves to her customers.

loans.use: To buy tailoring materials and two sewing machines

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr:
Kodjo K. is 40 years old, married, with three children. He lives in Assahoun, a village located about 50 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo. He has been selling frozen foods for more than five years. With this new loan, he wants increase the capacity of his business by purchasing fish, rump steak, chicken and sausages to sell. The profit from his business will allow him to better provide for his family’s needs.

Translated from French by Alison Dent, Kiva volunteer.

Kodjo K. est âgé de 40 ans, marié et père de 3 enfants. Il habite à Assahoun, un village situé à environ 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Monsieur Kodjo réside à Assahoun, un village situé à environ 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Il est revendeur de produits congelés depuis plus de 5 ans. Avec ce nouveau crédit, il souhaite acheter des poissons, des croupions, des poulets et des saucisses pour la revente en vue d’augmenter la capacité de son commerce. Les bénéfices de son activité lui permettront de mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: To purchase fish, rump steak, chicken and sausages to sell

loans.name: Zarbibi

texts.ru:
Zarbibi M. lives in the town of Tursun-zoda. She is 51 years old, married and has 6 children. She has a secondary education. Zarbibi sells sugar at the local Tursun-zoda market and has over 3 years experience in this business. She purchases sugar wholesale by bags and then sells it retail by kilograms. She needs the loan in order to purchase product wholesale. Zarbibi plans to repay the loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina, Kiva Volunteer.

Махмудова Зарбиби жительница города Турсунзаде.Возраст 51 год,замужем, имеет 6 детей. Образование среднее. Клиентка занимается куплей продажей сахарного песка. Реализует сахар на местном рынке города Турсунзаде. Имеет опыт в этой дейтельности более 3 лет. Она покупает сахар мешками оптом,а потом реализует его килограмми в розницу. Планирует закупить оптом товар, для чего ей нужны деньги.Планирует погасить кредит в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase product

loans.name: Fumilola

texts.en: Fumilola is 37 years old and she is married with four children. She has been in the business of hair styling for over ten years. Fumilayo sells hair materials like hair extensions, relaxer, and cream. She makes different hairstyles and her customers are happy with them. Her shop is open from 8AM to 7PM. With the steady increase in the number of her customers, she needs the loan amount of $450 to buy one hair dryer and hair materials. She says that this will make her customers patronize her more. She thanks you.

loans.use: Purchase one hair dryer and hair materials like hair extension, hair relaxer, hair cream.for sale.

loans.name: Nargiz

texts.en: Nargiz is married and has 3 children, one of whom is pictured in the photograph. Her family lives in a town called Khachmaz, where her son owns a taxi business which he started 4 years ago. At present, the family needs a loan of US$875 to buy spare parts to be able to improve the taxi business.

loans.use: Purchase of spare parts for a car

loans.name: Cynthia Janeth

texts.es:
La señora Cynthia es madre soltera tiene dos hijos menores de edad que están bajo su cuidado. El negocio que ella tiene es de reciclaje de metales que obtiene de autos que fueron desechados por estar casi destruidos, en accidentes.

La señora Cynthia informo que por el momento no cuenta con el capital necesario para comprar autos para reciclar los metales y venderlos por eso está solicitando un préstamo de $750.00 dlls. Para que su negocio genere ingresos y poder darles a sus hijos una mejor forma de vivir.

Este negocio aporta varios beneficios ya que al reciclar los metales y venderlos contribuye a mejorar la ecología, además que le aporta ingresos a su familia ya a la familia de por lo menos dos empleados que le ayudan a desmantelar los autos y separar los metales para la venta.
texts.en:
Cynthia is a single mother and she has two children who are still under her care. The business that she runs is recycling of metals that she obtains from cars that have been dismantled from accidents.

Cynthia stated that for the moment she does not have the necessary capital funds to pruchase cars destined for recycling. For this she is requesting a loan in the amount of $750 US. All so that her business will generate earnings significant enough to provide her children with a better way of life.

This business carries with it many benefits. Recycling metals for resale contributes towards a healthier environment, and in adition this provides an income to her family and to at least two employees that help her dismantle and separate the metals for resale.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase old scrap cars and destroyed cars from accidents.

loans.name: Luzvilla

texts.en:
Mrs. Luzvilla S. is a bonafide resident of Lower Langcangan, Oroquieta City, province of Misamis Occidental, Mindanao, Philippines. She has been a widow since 1993 and has four children. Hard work and determination are the only weapons she had at the time her husband died but she managed to send her children to school. She is the only one who supports the family through snack vending in offices, also having a part-time job at the hospital as a janitress. 

Change of governance was the cause for which she was terminated at the hospital where she worked for two years. Afterwards, she decided to have a small sari-sari store (general store) with a starting capital of two thousand pesos. In September 2001, a friend told her about Paglaum MPC: its program and services rendered to the members. She did not hesitate to join Paglaum MPC; she attended the membership seminar and became a bonafide member, too. 

From that time on, she requested loans as additional working capital for her sari-sari business.  As of now she is on her 26th loan amounting to Twenty thousand pesos. For the past loans, her good performance in repayment is highly appreciated. In such a way, she was able to send her children to school so that they have successfully finished their studies and have their respective jobs now. Lately, her daughters got married. Only one son and one daughter are still living with her. Future plans for the family are to have a decent house to live in, a bigger sari-sari store building, and adequate savings for her old age.

loans.use: To purchase additional grocery items for her store

loans.name: Auk

texts.en:
Auk S., 35, pictured with her husband, has two young children and lives in Kampong Cham with her husband. She sells rice and porridge from her home to earn a living and is able to make $4 US a day, while her husband operates a motor-taxi business. On average, he makes $3 US a day. Two of their children are students.

Auk S. is asking for a loan of $1200 US to purchase land to grow yams. This will give her family additional income to help raise its standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase land to grow yams.

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria E. J. sells fish. The demand for her fish is high and she hopes to meet the demand of her customers. She is 35 years old and married with 6 children. She needs the loan amount of N 50,000 to purchase more fish to sell to her customers. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to sell

loans.name: Juana

texts.es: A sus 43 años, Juana quiere seguir progresando, vive en su casa propia, junto a su pequeña hija Yamile, de solo 12 años, quien es el motivo de todos sus esfuerzos. Juana es una madre ejemplar, que disfruta de vender ropa y peluches en su pequeño puesto en la ciudad de Puno, es feliz ayudando y apoyando a sus vecinas vendedoras en mejorar su negocio, sabe que necesita mucha ayuda para mejorar su futuro y le es muy difícil conseguir los peluches que vende, pues los que ella vende son diferente y muy especiales. Tiene ya 4 años vistiendo a sus clientes, quiere en el futuro hacer crecer su puesto y que se convierta en uno de los más conocidos, su deseo es que su hija Yamile tenga las oportunidades que ella nunca tuvo y para ello trabaja sin descanso en espera de cumplir sus metas. Este es su segundo préstamo en MFP, Juana es la socia más puntual en sus cuotas, es por eso  que su banco comunal le tiene mucha confianza. Ahora planea invertir en un nuevo negocio, quiere poner un puesto de comida, ella se siente capaz de realizar ambos trabajos y no le disgusta la idea de trabajar más, con tal de mejorar sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Fourty-three years of age, Juana wants to continue to make progress. She lives in a house she owns with her young 12-year-old daughter Yamile who is the reason behind all her efforts. Juana is an exemplary mother who enjoys selling clothing and plush toys from her small store in the city of Puno. She is happy helping and supporting her neighbouring merchants in improving her business. She knows that it takes alot of help to make a better future and it is very difficult for her to get the plush toys she sells as hers are different and very special. She has been taking care of her customers for four years already and wants to expand her location in the future and that she can become one of the most renowned merchants. She hopes that her daughter Yamile will have opportunities which she never had and for her she works without rest hoping to accomplish her goals. This is her second loan with MFP; Juana is the most punctual member in her repayments and because of this her community bank has a great deal of confidence in her. She is now planning to invest in a new business: she wants to begin selling food and feels that she is capable of doing both jobs and does not mind the idea of working more as long as she improves her income.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Investment capital to open a new business.

loans.name: Nguyễn Thị Hoa Group

texts.vi:
Chị H., 40 tuổi, hiện đang sống cùng cH. và 3 con (2con đi học và 1 con ở nhà buôn bán cùng chị). CH. chị làm nghề xây dựng nên suốt ngày theo công trình không thể giúp chị bán hàng. Chị rất tháo vát nên 2 mẹ con chị đã mở cửa hàng H. quả rất có lộc. Thu nhập hàng ngày của gia đình chị khoảng 150000-170000 vnđ/ ngày. Lần này chị vay 4704000 vnđ/chu kì 2/ 50 tuần để bổ sung vốn buôn bán H. quả. Các thành viên còn lại trong nhóm của chị:
 Chị Chu Thị B. vay 4256000 vnđ/ 50 tuần để mua nguyên liệu tráng bánh đa nem.
 Chị Nguyễn Thị H. vay 4704000 vnđ/ 50 tuần để thêm vốn buôn bán H. quả.
 Chị Dương Thị H. vay 4704000 vnđ/ 50 tuần để thêm vốn bán quần áo.
 Chị Đặng Thị Hường vay 4704000 vnđ/ 50 tuần để thêm vốn bán quần áo.
texts.en:
Mrs. H., 40 years old, is living with her husband and three children (two of them go to school, and one stays at home helping her). Her husband is a worker at construction sites and cannot help her to trade. She is very active, and her fruit shop has good business. The daily income of her family is about VND150,000-170,000. In this second loan cycle, she borrows VND4,704,000 for 50 weeks to invest more in buying and reselling fruits. Other members in her group include: + Ms. Chu Thi B. borrows VND4,256,000 in 50 weeks to buy supplies for dried rice pancake. + Mrs . Nguyen Thi Hoi borrows VND4,704,000 in 50 weeks to invest in fruit trading + Mrs. Duong Thi Hong borrows VND4,704,000 in 50 weeks to invest more in clothes trading + Mrs Dang Thi Huong borrows VND4,704,000 in 50 weeks to invesst more in clothes trading.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: vay vốn buôn bán

loans.name: Lely

texts.es: La señora Lely tiene 47 años de edad, es madre de tres hijos en edad escolar, viven todos juntos con su esposo quien siempre la apoya en la realización de sus objetivos. Gracias a su trabajo la casa que habitan es propia. Desde hace 5 años se dedica a la costura, a razón de haber estudiado este oficio y de ser una de las mejores de su localidad. Lely confecciona ropa para niños y adultos en todos los modelos y gustos, sus trabajos los realiza sola y dentro de su casa, y hasta ahora le ha ido muy bien. Lo que le gusta de su trabajo es dar lo mejor de ella en cada prenda, para que sus clientes estén satisfechos y regresen siempre, además de recomendarla a otros por el buen trabajo que realiza. En el futuro Lely quiere tener una tienda de ropa elaborada por ella misma. Son cerca de 4 años los que viene trabajando con MFP, este es su 7mo préstamos, y le gusta participar con su grupo porque existe mucha comunicación entre ellos, y para ella eso es muy importante para un buen trabajo en equipo. Con el dinero que solicita en esta ocasión comprará materiales de costura; telas, hilos, broches, etc., haciendo un gasto de 1500 soles; lo restante lo invertirá en el negocio de su esposo quien es técnico dental.
texts.en:
Señora Lely is 47. She is the mother of three school-aged children. All of them live together along with her husband, who always supports her in reaching her goals. Thanks to her hard work, the house that they live in is their own. For five years, she has made a living through sewing. She studied this trade, and she is one of the best seamstresses in her area. Lely makes clothing for children and adults in all designs and styles. She does her work alone inside her house. It has gone very well for her. What she likes about her job is doing her best on each article of clothing so her customers will be satisfied and always return and recommend her to others because of the good job that she does. In the future, Lely wants to have a clothing store with clothing made by her. She has worked with Microfinanzas Prisma for close to four years. This is her seventh loan, and she likes to participate in this group because there is a lot of communication among the members. For her, it is very important to work as a team. With the money she is requesting, she will buy sewing materials: fabric, thread, fasteners, etc. She will spend 1500 soles on this. The rest she will invest in the business of her husband, who is a dental technician.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sewing supplies

loans.name: Nema

texts.en: Nema M. is a 45-year-old mother of three. Her husband, Noli, is a utility worker. She raises pigs and sells fish and vegetables in the village to support the needs of the family. She applied for this loan to buy a motor engine for the boat she wants to establish for her son Peter, who graduated college and wishes to have a job to support his parents, especially in the education of his sister and younger brother. She wants to save money to establish a bigger fishing boat in the future.

loans.use: To buy motor engine for pump boat

loans.name: Alba Luz

texts.es: la Sra. Alba Luz M. Blandon se dedica al comercio , ella cuenta con un pequeño negocio de venta  de Calzado y Ropa Americana" tiene mas 5 años dedicarse a este tipo de actividad y durante todo este tiempo  le ha ido muy  bien esta casada tiene 2 hijos a los que apoya con los gastos educativos y en el hogar uno de sus sueños es tener una gran tienda  en la que pueda emplear personas y de esta forma contribuir a crear fuentes de empleo ,hay que buscar nuevas alternativas para poder salir adelante , ella es una mujer con un espiritu de superacion, con el credito que me brinden tan prestigiada institucion lograre dar un paso muy importante ya que surtire mas mi negocio. esas fueron las palabras de  doña Albita
texts.en:
Mrs. Alba Luz M. Blandon is a businesswoman. She has a small business selling shoes and American clothing. She has been in this business for more than 5 years, during which time she has had a lot of success. Alba is married and has two children, whom she supports by covering their educational expenses and housing. One of her dreams is to own a large shop where she can hire staff and, in doing so, create employment opportunities. Alba must look for new alternatives to be able to get ahead. She has a strong desire to better herself. According to Alba, she will use the requested loan to make an important step forward by expanding her shop's stock of merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Todd M. Anderson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of shoes and clothing such as skirts, shirts, trousers, blouses and dresses

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana K. sells groundnut paste and is asking for a loan to stock more groundnuts for making paste. She is twenty years old and married to a driver. Diana has no children.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a rental house.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more groundnuts for making paste.

loans.name: Maria Isidra

texts.es: Maria Isidra G. L. vive Apopa ubicado en el departamento de San Salvador, Maria está acompañada vive con su pareja y sus dos hijos, Jose de 8 años de edad y Glenda de 7 años de edad, ambos niños asisten a la escuela. Aníbal la pareja de Maria se dedica a la crianza y reventa de ganado con estos ingresos el logra aportar económicamente a la familia pero Maria no queda de brazos cruzados en su casa, ella también ha buscado hacer su negocio y ahora ha logrado estabilizar una venta de productos como ropa y zapatos. Maria sale de su casa todos los días y se va a vender de manera ambulante a otros departamentos de El Salvador como Sonsonate, San Miguel, San Salvador entre otros. Maria solicita este crédito por que quiere surtir su inventario de productos.
texts.en:
Maria Isidra G. L. lives in Apopa, in the state of San Salvador. She lives with her partner and their two children, José, who is 8 and Glenda, who is 7. Both children attend school. Anibal, Maria's partner, raises and sells cattle, and supports the family with his income. Maria doesn't sit at home with her arms crossed, however. She also works and has established a business selling products like clothing and shoes. She goes out every day and is a traveling sales person in other states of El Salvador such as Sonsonate, San Miguel, and San Salvador, among others. Maria is requesting this loan to increase her inventory of products.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

location.town: Apopa en el departamento de San Salvador

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda M., 55 years old, has 3 children. She lives in Navalan, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She has been engaged in fruit vending for 2 years now. She joined Paglaum MPC and has received three loans already.

Recently she applied for the amount of PHP 10,000 as additional capital for her fruit vending. The profit she generates from her fruit business will be used in purchasing textiles and to make into curtains for added income. Rosalinda makes use of her time in working at a hobby and at the same time making an additional income.

loans.use: expansion of her fruit vending business

loans.name: Gladis

texts.es: Gladis tiene 62 años, es viuda, vive en su casa propia con el menor D. su hijo D. 14 años. DesD. hace18 años se dedica a la costura D. faldas y fustanes típicos D. su zona, su principal herramienta D. trabajo es su máquina D. coser que tiene desD. hace muchos años atrás. Lo bueno es que su trabajo lo realiza todos los días en la comodidad D. su casa, generalmente por las mañanas, ya que por las tardes cuida D. sus animales. Su hijo la apoya en la comercialización D. las faldas y las reparte a domicilio como un servicio adicional para sus clientes. El deseo D. Gladis es aumentar su producción para incrementar sus ganancias. Esta es la primera vez que tiene un préstamo con MFP y quiere ser una socia muy comprometidas que vele por el bienestar común D. su banco comunal. El dinero que viene solicitando será destinado a la compra D. tela para confeccionar mayor variedad D. diseños D. faldas.
texts.en:
Gladis is 62 years old, a widow, and lives in a house she owns with her son’s youngest child who is 14 years old. For 18 years, she has dedicated herself to sewing skirts and petticoats typical of her region. Her main tool is her sewing machine, which she has had for many years. The good thing is that she can realize her work, every day, from the comfort of her own home. She generally sews in the mornings, so that she can use the afternoon to tend to her animals. Her son helps her with the selling of her skirts, and delivers them to their customers’ homes as an added service. Gladis’ wish is to augment her production of her product, so she can increase her earnings. This is the first time she is taking a loan through MFP, and she wants to be a reliable member who contributes toward the overall well-being of her cooperative bank. The funds she is requesting will be destined for buying fabrics to make a greater variety of skirt designs.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fabrics.

loans.name: Chon's Group

texts.en:
This loan is for a small group of five low-income people who live in Siem Reap province. Chon S., 36, has been chosen as leader of this group loan by the other members.

Chon S. is a single mother blessed with two teenage children. One of her children works in a restaurant and receives a fixed salary and the other attends school. To generate a daily income, Chon S. sells used clothing in, and around the outside of, a local market. She earns around $2 USD per day. She has now attracted a large number of regular customers so her business is going well, but she complains that she lacks money to expand and upgrade her successful investment. She is therefore requesting a loan in order to accrue a larger quantity of clothing to sell.

R. will use the loan to build a new house to make family living conditions more comfortable.

R., a fish catcher, will use the loan to buy a boat for fishing.

S. will use the loan to purchase more nets for fishing.

C. is looking for a loan to buy a machine to adapt an existing boat for fishing purposes.

loans.use: To purchase a larger quantity of clothing to sell

loans.name: Valentina

texts.es:
La señora Valentina es socia del Banco Comunal “Chijuyo Copapujo”, ubicado en el Centro Poblado de Chijuyo Copapujo del distrito de Ilave, provincia de El Collao, en el departamento de Puno, ella tiene 35 años de edad, estado civil casada y madre de 1 hijo, tiene estudios primaria completa, vive en la Comunidad de Chijuyo Copapujo.

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos desde hace 3 años, su primer préstamo fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles, monto que le lo utilizara como capital para la crianza de animales menores.

Actualmente, ella requiere un préstamo adicional, por ello viene solicitando la suma de S/. 500.00 nuevos soles, con este monto ella va adquirir cabuya para la fabricación de sogas, también va a comprar animales menores  para engorde, para venderlos en las ferias de la zona.

Su deseo es abrir un nuevo negocio.

A ella le gusta que las promotoras vengan al lugar donde ellas viven.
texts.en:
Valentina is a member of the Chijuyo Copapujo Community Bank, which is located in the Chijuyo Copapujo town center in the Ilave district, El Collao province, Puno department. She is 35, married, and has one child. She has an elementary school education. She lives in the Chijuyo Copapujo community. She has worked with the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for three years. She used her first loan of 300 PEN as capital for raising small animals. She currently needs another loan for 500 PEN. She will use the loan to buy pita fiber for making ropes. She will also buy small animals to fatten and sell at the regional fairs. Her wish is to open a new business. She likes that the agency personnel come to where the community bank members live.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pita fiber to make ropes and small animals to fatten

loans.name: Devotha

texts.en:
Devotha is a member of the Idunda D borrower group in Ilala,Iringa,she is 20 years old woman,she is singe,she cares for 1 dependent.

Devotha started her own business selling fabric materials like kanga,vitenge 5 years ago,she works 8 hours a day and earn monthly profit approximately 145,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Devotha first loan from BRAC_Tanzania,she requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more materials for sale.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan,Devotha hopes to save money and expand her business

loans.use: To buy more fabric materials

loans.name: Tuya

texts.en:
Y. Tuya is 43 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia's capital city. Her oldest son, Ganga, has lived and studied in Japan for the past six years, while her younger two daughters attend university and high school in Mongolia. Her husband works as carpenter in a small wooden-products factory in the city.  Tuya operates a jeans-selling business out of two rented stalls at a popular indoor market and trade center. She has a shop assistant who helps her operate both stalls. She also supplements her income by working as a Mongolian language teacher at a center for foreign nationals. 

Tuya started her jeans business in 2001 and has had much success. Today, her profits average between 400,000 - 500,000 tugrugs per month. She attributes her success to her good management and accounting practices. In the future, Tuya hopes to continue to grow her business so that she can provide for her children's education.  As the new school year has just begun, Tuya hopes to purchase more products to sell to the many students who will be buying new clothes this fall and winter. She is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug loan ($2,150) to buy supplies for her jeans-selling business.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her jeans-selling business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: achat d'huile à moteur

loans.name: Feliciana

texts.es:
La señora FELICIANA P. A., tiene 43 años, vive en el distrito de Trujillo, provincia de Trujillo, departamento La Libertad – Perú. La socia pertenece al Banco Comunal SAN LUIS  y presenta estudios hasta 3ero. de Primaria y tiene 3 hijos todos menores que dependen económicamente de ella. Feliciana se dedica a la  venta de azúcar, arroz, galletas, jugos, gaseosa, golosinas, etc en la tienda que tiene en su casa. Con su  primer crédito de 300 nuevos soles comprará azúcar, arroz, galletas, jugos, gaseosa, golosinas, etc para vender en la tienda de su casa.
Con este crédito de 300  nuevos soles comprará sacos de arroz, azúcar, galletas, gaseosas, aceite, fideo, etc.
texts.en:
FELICIANA P. A. is 43 years old, lives in the Trujillo district, Trujillo province, La Libertad department, Peru. She is a member of the SAN LUIS communal bank and has finished third grade. She has three minor children all of whom are dependent upon her. Feliciana sells sugar, rice, crackers, fruit juices, soft drinks, snacks, etc. from a grocery store that she operates from her home. With her first 300 sol loan she purchased supplies such as rice, sugar, crackers, juices, soft drinks, snacks, etc. to stock her store. With this new loan she will do the same.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sacks of rice, sugar, crackers, soft drinks, pasta, etc.

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan, 43, works as a farmer and as a bricklayer. When Juan was a little boy, his father abandoned their family. At that point, to help support his family, Juan learned agriculture and dairy cow farming. Juan has been married for over twenty years, and has six children whose ages range from 2 to 19 years. They are a poor family with few economic resources. Their oldest daughter, who could only attended primary school, is now working in Argentina and sending helpful remittances back to her family.

Juan lives in a small home in the community of Chaupisuyo, which is in the city of Cochabamba. He has three dairy cows that produce milk. Juan sells the milk to a business that turns it into various milk products. This loan will be used to purchase another dairy cow, which will help Juan grow his milk production. That will help him increase his profits and improve the quality of life for his family. He hopes to use the extra earnings to remodel his home and help his five younger children pursue professional careers.

loans.use: To purchase another dairy cow

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Madame Mariam O. est âgée  de 45 ans, mariée mère de 7 enfants et vivant dans une famille polygame  dans le quartier Wala- Wala de la préfecture de Koutiala (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Pour des raisons sociales, elle n’a pas pu aller à l’école faire des études comme ses autres frères et sœurs de la famille. 
Afin de parvenir à satisfaire ses besoins, Mariam a commencé les activités génératrices  de revenus depuis son enfance auprès de sa mère et  exerce pour elle-même depuis  maintenant 15 ans.  
Elle est très bien connue  dans le secteur de la vente des condiments alimentaires  et  cette activité lui procure assez de revenus.  
Pour mener à bien sa vente enfin de satisfaire sa clientèle, elle n’a pas pris du temps à rejoindre  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis 4 ans.  
Après  4 prêts  solidaires (prêt de groupe) tous payés correctement sans difficulté, elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel, tous les deux précédents ont été bien remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter, plusieurs colis de différentes variétés de condiments alimentaires  à Sikasso et à Koutiala. Elle  effectue sa vente à son domicile à une clientèle essentiellement féminine, au comptant et quelques fois à crédit.   
Elle compte réaliser un  bénéfice  mensuel de  80.000 FCFA qu’elle envisage utiliser pour le remboursement des d’intérêts du prêt, utiliser le bénéfice restant pour payer les frais de scolarité de ses enfants et investir le reste  dans son  activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Mariam O., aged 45, is married and the mother of seven children living in a polygamous family in the Wala-Wala district of Koutiala prefecture (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali).  For societal reasons, she couldn't go to school to study, as did her brothers and sisters in the family.  To achieve meeting her needs, Mariam started a revenue-generating business with her mother when a child, and she has been working in it on her own for fifteen years.  She is very well-known in the sector of selling condiments, which is a business bringing in enough income for her. To carry out her sales in order to satisfy her customers, Mariam wasted no time in joining the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso four years ago.  After four solidarity loans (group loans), all repaid properly without a problem, she is now on her third individual loan.  The preceding ones have all been repaid.   She intends to buy several packets of different types of condiments in Sikasso and in Koutiala.  She sells out of her home to customers essentially of women, who pay in cash and sometimes on credit.  Mariam plans on realizing a monthly profit of 80,000 francs CFA that she envisions using to repay the loan interest.  The remaining profit will be used to cover the schooling costs for her children and to invest in her business. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy condiments

loans.name: Caren

texts.en:
Caren C. is a 30-year-old mother of 5. Caren is married to Francis Suter who is 45 years old.

Caren operates a cosmetics shop and salon, from which she generates profits of about Kshs 10,000 a month. She started this business five years ago. Caren's loan from KADET is worth Kshs 80,000. It's her second loan, and she repaid the first well. With this loan, Caren plans to purchase stock for her business since during the December festive season she has an increase in clients. Some of the items include cosmetics, hair treatment chemicals, synthetic hair and extra dryers.

KADET Ltd is Caren’s first and only financier (MFI); she was introduced to KADET by a community leader who is a KADET client.

Caren does her business in Kabarnet town; her clients are residents of Kabarnet town. If her business flourishes Caren plans to expand her business from retail to wholesale.

Caren dreams of opening a cosmetic wholesale shop and she describes herself as hard-working and determined to attain her goals.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: to buy cosmetics and a hair-drying machine

loans.name: Madinatou

texts.fr: H. Madinatou est née en 1978 au Bénin. Madinatou vit depuis près de 15 ans à Hindé à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à KOUKPAKI François, Madinatou est mère de deux enfants, tous scolarisés. Madinatou vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple a un autre enfant à charge, en plus de leurs enfants. C'est principalement le mari qui assure les charges de la famille ; cependant, Madinatou vient en aide à son mari dans l'entretien et l'éducation des enfants. Madinatou n'a pas été à l'école, mais a appris la coiffure. Madinatou exerce cette activité depuis plus de 5 ans. A côté de cette activité, Madinatou vend des mèches, des produits cosmétiques et divers autres articles dont les bombons, etc. dans son atelier à Hindé. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Madinatou s'approvisionne. Madinatou a déjà obtenu deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qu'elle a bien remboursés. En vue de renforcer davantage son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle, Madinatou sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Madinatou H. was born in 1978 in Benin. Madinatou has been living in the Hindé area of Cotonou, Benin's economic capital, for 15 years. Married to François KOUKPAKI, Madinatou is a mother of two children. They both attend school. Madinatou lives together with her children and her husband. The couple provides for another child in addition to their own. The husband is the main provider for the family; however, Madinatou assists her husband in the care and education of the children. Madinatou did not go to school, but she learned hairdressing. Madinatou has been in this business for over 5 years. Aside from this business, Madinatou sells hair extensions, cosmetics and various other items (incl. confectionery) in her studio in Hindé. Madinatou gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin's International market. Madinatou has already been granted two loans from ALIDé and paid them back without incident. Madinatou is requesting a third loan from ALIDé with the objective of reinforcing her activity and increasing her customers' satisfaction.

Translated from French by Charlotte Buecheler, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of hair extension and cosmetic supplies.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth sells dried fish and crayfish from her stall. She also owns a grinding machine which she uses to grind tomatoes, peppers and beans. With these combined businesses, she sells for long hours to enable her to support her family.

She hopes for a loan amount of 100,000 NGN to purchase more dried fish and crayfish to sell. She hopes to expand her business in the future.

Elizabeth is 50 years old and married with seven children. Her youngest child is fourteen years old. Her husband works with a government firm, and he also supports the home. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish and crayfish to sell

loans.name: Leah

texts.en: Leah O. is from the village of Libertad Alto, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 50 years old. Leah is married and has four adult children. To make a living, Leah sells a variety of dry goods. Leah has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 3,200 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2007, Leah joined PMPC, a Kiva partner, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leah has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6,000 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Leah is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Leah from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Ly C., 42, is a professional handicrafter living and working at home in Takeo province. Since 1993, she has been using beads and other materials to make flowers on women's clothing to earn a living and typically makes US$ 2 each day. Decorated dresses are a Khmer tradition and people wear them during the 'Water Festival', 'P’chum Ben' or Khmer New Year. It takes around 7-10 days to complete each dress and its price is expensive, of course. Most people prefer hand-made rather than machine-made.

Ly C. said she learned how to decorate dresses from her mother and she started doing that business when she was not yet married. Ly C. would like a loan of US$ 400 to purchase more beads and other materials for her work.

loans.use: To purchase more beads, etc. for her work

loans.name: Dembagnouman Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Dembagnouman est composé de six femmes mariées majoritairement dans des familles polygames avec en moyenne 50 ans et 6 enfants. Elles habitent le village de Togo dans la préfecture de Ségou (4ème Région administrative du Mali).
Ces femmes se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de mariage et de parenté. Elles font essentiellement le commerce d’articles divers.
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs fonds de commerce, elles ont intégré Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leurs à leur  6ème  prêt solidaire, après avoir correctement remboursé les cinq précédents. 
Ce nouveau prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 150 mortiers, 200 sacs de charbon de bois, 5 sacs de riz, 10 sacs de mil et 15 sacs de farine de blé. 
Elles s’approvisionnent dans le grand marché de Ségou, à Noumou Wêrê et dans les villages environnants. Les produits sont revendus à domicile, dans la foire de Ségou et en ambulant, en espèce ou à crédit à une clientèle  composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 28 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser le prêt de Soro Yiriwaso et subvenir aux besoins de la famille. 
Elles ont pour ambition d’acheter des bœufs de labour qui leurs permettront de cultiver une grande surface d’arachide et d’haricot.
texts.en:
The Dembagnouman group comprises six married women, mostly from polygamous families. On average, they are 50 years old and have six children. They live in the village of Togo in Ségou prefecture in Mali's 4th administrative region. They have ties to their neighbors and with their birth families and their families by marriage, and are in the business of selling various products. To increase working capital, they have had five loans from Soro Yiriwaso (all properly repaid) and have applied for a sixth. They want to buy 150 mortars, 200 bags of charcoal, 5 sacks of rice, 10 sacks of millet and 15 sacks of wheat flour in the big market in Ségou, at Noumou Wêrê, and in neighboring villages. The goods would be sold from their homes, at the fair in Ségou, and by going door to door, for cash or credit, to both men and women. They hope for income of 28,000 CFA a month, with which they will pay back Soro Yiriwaso and take care of family expenses. Their ambition is to buy oxen so that they work a large field, growing peanuts and beans.

Translated from French by Michael Briggs, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various items for retail sale.

loans.name: Olinda Marisol

texts.es:
Marisol es socia del Banco Comunal Anabella.
Marisol es soltera, tiene 38 años y 3 hijos, Marisol tiene una tienda en la ciudad de Huancayo en donde vende abarrotes en general y otros productos. Además Marisol vende ropa, zapatos al por mayor en la ciudad de Ayacucho.
Marisol necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de zapatillas.
Los sueños de Marisol son tener casa propia, y tener un local propio.
texts.en:
Marisol is a member of the communal bank "Anabella." She is single, 38 years old, and has 3 children. Marisol has a store in the city of Huancayo where she sells groceries and other general merchandise. In addition, she sells clothing and shoes wholesale in the city of Ayacucho. Marisol needs a loan of 2,000 Peruvian soles which she will invest in the purchase of sneakers. Marisol dreams of having her own home, and having her own place for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy sneakers

loans.name: Dy

texts.en:
Dy S., age 38, is married and resides with her children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She has four children. She is engaged in a business of selling wooden furniture, earning an income of $5.50 per day to help cover the family expenses. The family is also assisted by her husband, who sells firewood, earning an income of $5 per day. Their standard of living has been improved since S. and her husband have had these businesses. 

S. is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase more firewood and furniture to sell. This is her second loan from CREDIT, a partner of Kiva.

loans.use: Buy firewood and wooden furniture for sale

loans.name: Roya Lema Group

texts.en:
Lema is the group leader of Roya Lema group. She lives in district 9 of Kabul Afghanistan. She is married with four children who are in school, and she supports all her family members through her monthly income.

Lema is a carpet weaver and would like to expand her business. She needs the loan to buy good quality weaving materials and then weave her carpets which are in high demand in the bazaar.

She wants to grow her business and to support her children with a better education.

loans.use: To purchase supplies for weaving carpets.

loans.name: Luke

texts.en: Luke is 33 years old and married with two children who are in school. He sells furniture such as wall units, tables and sofa sets in his home town to earn a living. He has been in the business for seven years and has two employees. Luke also earns some extra income from teaching income generating activities to the youths from his church. He saves his money with his group in Faulu Kenya called Wangige Business Pioneers. This enables him to access loans because the group guarantees repayment. He hopes to grow his business and venture into other businesses in the future. He has requested for a loan of KES 20,000 form Faulu Kenya to buy more furniture to sell.

loans.use: To buy more furniture to sell.

loans.name: Romila Nawid Group

texts.en: Romila is a member of Romila Nawid group. She lives in district 8th of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and has four children. Her husband has a public call office (PCO), where he works, and all the family members benefit through the income he generates. She wants to take a loan for her husband to buy new sets of telephones to attract more clients. He hopes to develop his business in a short time and to be a good business dealer.

loans.use: Towards purchasing sets of telephones.

loans.name: Cicila

texts.en: Cicila A. is currently in the business of selling tomatoes, onions and cooking oil and is requesting a loan to stock fresh and dried fish to sell. Cicila is 45 years old and is widowed. She has six children and her children do not go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for her children. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock fresh and dried fish to sell

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhum K., aged 57, operates her own small business selling various vegetables. Arising early in the morning, she travels to where the vegetable are sold in bulk, making her purchases and then hurrying to retail them in the local busy market, thereby earning enough money to cover her family's living expenses.

Chhum K. has a life partner in her husband, who appears on the right in the photo. He lost a limb during the civil war and currently works planting crops on his own farmland. Married many years, the couple is blessed with four children, one of whom is now married. Chhum K.’s husband wants to generate extra income as a taxi driver, so she is now requesting a loan to purchase a motorcycle with an attached trailer to enable him to start the service.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle with an attached trailer.

loans.name: Nilda

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “ARCANGEL GABRIEL”; La socia vive en el distrito de Huanchac en la provincia de Cusco departamento del Cusco.

La  socia es la Sra. Nilda;  ella tiene 39 años de edad y La socia es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos de  7 años y el otro de 9 meses;  La socia es docente de profesión en el colegio Abraham Lincon; ella enseña a la primaria, La socia desea el préstamo para poder hacer pago de una mensualidad de su hijo en el colegio, esto debido a que ella designo por urgencia su sueldo de este mes en la compra de medicamentos para los bronquios de su menor hijo. La socia solicita el préstamo para pagar una mensualidad e su menor hijo en el colegio. 
 
La socia valora y agradece el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio, así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo estipulado.
texts.en:
This member belongs to the “Arcangel Gabriel” Communal Bank. She lives in the Huanchac district of Cusco province, in the Cusco region of Peru.
39-year-old Nilda lives with her partner and 2 children, aged 7 and 9 months. Nilda works as a teacher at the Abraham Lincoln School; she is a primary school teacher.
Nilda is requesting this loan to pay for her son’s monthly school fees because she has had to put her salary towards paying for her younger son’s bronchial medication.
Nilda appreciates this loan, and is committed to making her payments on time.

Translated from Spanish by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To pay for her son's monthly school fees

loans.name: Leng

texts.en: Leng S., 20, is married and resides with her husband and a child in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for quality palm products. S. is a tailor and earns an income of USD 2.00 each per day. Her husband is a driver for a farm in the province, earning an income of USD 4.50 per day to help cover the family's expenses. S. is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase a plot of farmland to expand the family farming business. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a plot of farmland.

loans.name: Benkadi 3 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi 3 est composé de dix femmes, toutes mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles. Elles ont un âge moyen de 34 ans et 3 enfants par femme. Elles habitent le village de Korobougou dans la commune rurale de Sébougou  dans la 4ème région administrative du Mali, qu’est Ségou. 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de parenté et de leurs activités. Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture pendant l’hivernage, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er cycle de prêt de campagne. Les membres du groupe vont cultiver essentiellement de l’arachide, du mil et du gombo.
Madame Nana B. compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, 3 sacs de complexe céréale, 25 kg de semence d’arachide, recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de sarclage dans ses champs. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants à la foire de Ségou. Les activités de labour des champs sont l’œuvre des hommes alors que le désherbage est effectué par l’association des femmes du village. 
Sur sa superficie de 2,9 hectares, Madame Nana  B. compte réaliser 6 sacs de mil, 20 sacs d’arachide et une vingtaine de tasse de gombo. Une partie de la récolte des céréales est auto consommée tandis que le reste est vendu. 
Le bénéfice obtenu est utilisé pour prendre en charge la scolarisation des enfants et les petits besoins du foyer.
texts.en:
The group Benkadi 3 is made up of ten women, all married with large traditional families. The women are 34 years old on average and an average of 3 children per woman. They live in the village of Korobougou in the rural community of Sébougou in the 4th administrative region of Mali, which is Ségou. They know one another through marital, parentage and business ties. With the goal of increasing the extent of their crop during the winter, they appealed to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first farm loan. The group members will mainly cultivate peanuts, millet and gumbo. Mrs. Nana B. expects to use her loan to buy 3 bags of complex grains, 25 kg of peanut seeds, and to recruit a labor force for hard labor activities and hoeing in the fields. She obtains her supplies at the fair in Ségou. The business of laboring in the fields is men's work, while the weeding is done by the association of women in the village. In an area of 2.9 hectares, Mrs. Nana B. expects to get 6 bags of millet, 20 bags of peanuts and 20 cups of gumbo. A part of the grain harvest is consumed by herself, while the rest is sold. The profit obtained will be used to provide for the schooling of her children and the small needs of the household.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fertilizer (complex grains), peanut seeds, and to use a labor force for laboring and hoeing.

loans.name: Darryl

texts.en:
Darryl L. is from the village of Casusan in the municipality of Aloran in Misamis Occidental Province. He is 28 years old. Darryl is married and has one school-age child. To make a living, Darryl works in someone else's service-based business. The main source of income for this business comes from providing general services in "motor repair" to local community members. Darryl has been engaged in this business for over 5 years, and he earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Darryl joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Darryl has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC. Darryl is requesting a new loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Darryl from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Ana Francisca

texts.es: La Sra. P. M. es comerciante del mercado la estación, inicia a elaborar la comida a la 3:00 am posteriormente se traslada al mercado para realizar sus ventas y finaliza a las 9:00 am, la Sra. P. ha utilizado los créditos que CEPRODEL le ha otorgado para la compra al por mayor de los productos para la elaboración de comida donde obtiene mayor ganancia y así ha podido mejorar su nivel de vida, este negocio lo inicio en su vivienda con un capital de C$ 500.00 producto de aportes de sus hijos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Palacion M. is a merchant in the La Estación Market. She starts to make food at 3am which she then takes to the market to sell. She finishes work at 9am. Mrs. P. has used CEPRODEL loans to buy the products she needs to make her dishes at wholesale thereby earning higher profits and improving her standard of living. She started this business in her home with an initial investment of 500 colones that her children gave her.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood, rice, beans, eggs, etc.

loans.name: Ruharo Twimukye Group, Bushenyi

texts.en:
K. Slivia of Ruharo Twimukye group, Bushenyi, a mature happily-married father of 2 children, has been running a salon business for 12 years from Ruharo Trading centre, Bushenyi, alongside other agricultural activities. With all her efforts, she has been able to maintain earning 180,000 Ugandan shillings on a monthly basis. This income has always been significant in contributing towards her family's welfare. Her current set-back is lacking additional capital to purchase salon materials such as hair cutting machines, shampoo, hair oils and a drier (the basics demanded her lady customers) and further investing in her farming projects for better yields

Therefore, this loan will help Slivia in restocking business requirements that will see her get more sales revenue as she looks at opening a bigger salon in a large town and educating her children.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Keyla Sofía

texts.en:
Keyla is a 32-year-old single mother who lives with her two children in Alajuela, located near the central valley of Costa Rica. Keyla has a business selling various stationary items including ink cartridges, blank CD´s, DVD´s, and other computer hardware/software/office supplies. Additionally, she offers cell phone top-up and photocopying services. Keyla plans to use this loan to invest in ink cartridges in order to fill her store with more inventory items in an effort to attract more customers. 

Being a single mother and business owner, Keyla must be organized. Her days are jam packed, as she operates within the constraints of a tight schedule. Keyla wakes up at 5:30 AM in order to prepare breakfast for her children, get them ready for school, and carry out domestic tasks. She brings her children to school around 7:00 AM, then between 7 and 8 Keyla does her exercises in order to be able to open the store by 8:30 AM. At mid day, she closes her store to eat lunch; she re-opens the store at 1:30 PM and works until 6:00 PM. At this time, she helps her children with their school work and prepares dinner. She usually goes to bed by 9:30 PM.

In terms of goals and aspirations, Keyla has many. The idea is to expand her business and increase income so that she can continue to provide quality food, shelter and education for her children. Her ambition is for her business to become an established corporation in her community, offering various services to meet the needs of a diverse range of clients. Her major motivation is the sustenance of her family, and to provide a  positive example for her children. The values she wishes to instill are those of ambition, hard work, strength and a fighting spirit. It is of special importance, a source of pride to Keyla, to be able to support a dignified home and living conditions. 

Keyla has mentioned the importance of having a good credit history.  Like many micro-entrepreneurs, Keyla has found it difficult to secure a source of financing for working capital. She says that in order to surmount this challenge, it is important to project a positive image (as you can see in the picture). She says that once you are approved for credit, you must be punctual with repayments and responsible with the credit allowed you. She says a good credit history can opens doors and speaks to the general caliber of an individual´s nature.

loans.use: For the purchase of ink cartridges

loans.name: Bong

texts.en: Bong T. N. is 55 years old and has one child. She is a farmer who grows corn, rice and vegetables in paddies of 1,500 square meters. As she has  a lot of experience in farming, she can meet the full food demand of her  family and generate a stable daily income. Since joining our credit program in 2007, she has always been in a good repayment situation. Now she wants a loan of 7,194,000 VND to buy fertilizer and seed  for the next crop.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seed for the next crop.

loans.name: Assouma

texts.en: Assouma is 20 years old. She is married and has one child who is two and a half years old. Her husband is a businessman selling second-hand clothes. Assouma sells clothes as well. She has spent two years in this business. With this loan she will buy more clothes to sell. She plans to build a house with profits made from this business. She says that her business is successful because of its strategic location in relation to her customers.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Odinga

texts.en:
Odinga T., aged 36 years, is a livestock trader. He is married to Kilena who is a farmer, and together they have three children aged fifteen, ten and four years. Odinga operates his livestock trading business in Enkaroni market in Kajiado which is a very busy market. He also sells his cattle to traders from Kitengela and to the Kenya meat commission for slaughter as well. Odinga has been running this business for eleven years, and his monthly profit is 25,000 KES.

Odinga was introduced to Kadet by the credit officer in charge of Kitengela’s office. He has applied for a 40,000 KES loan which he plans to use to buy cows and part of it will be used to buy goats for trade. If the loan boosts the business, Odinga will buy a pickup to help in transporting his livestock to other markets.

Odinga describes himself as hardworking and ambitious. He dreams of opening a butchery in Enkaroni market so as to sell meat to customers at retail as well as continuing in his livestock trade.

loans.use: To buy livestock for trading

loans.name: Gladys

texts.es:
Gladys es una madre de familia de 37 años de edad que reside en el distrito de Olmos, una zona agrícola bastante comercial que pertenece a la provincia de Lambayeque y se encuentra situada a más de una hora y media de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Ella cuenta con una pequeña bodega instalada en su domicilio. Allí ofrece en venta a los vecinos y clientes de la zona diversos productos de consumo diario, entre productos de primera necesidad y abarrotes. El negocio cuenta con muy buena acogida debido a la buena calidad de los productos que ofrece y a la buena atención que brindan. Con los ingresos que le brinda esta actividad ella se encarga de ayudar con el sostenimiento económico de su familia.

La creciente demanda que su bodega ha venido experimentando ha hecho que piense en ampliarla adquiriendo más productos, por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1000 nuevos soles.
texts.en:
Gladys is a 37-year-old mother who lives in Olmos district, an agricultural and rather commercial area that belongs to the province of Lambayeque and is located more than an hour and a half away from the city of Chiclayo.

She has a small grocery store she runs from her home. That´s where she offers for sale a range of different everyday consumer products, including staples and groceries, to neighbours and customers from the area. The business is very well received because of the high quality of the products on offer as well as the good service provided. With the income she obtains from running the business she financialy supports her family. 

The growing demand experienced by her shop has made her want to expand it by acquiring additional products. That´s why she is requesting a loan of 1000 soles to Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: Buy products to expand her business.

loans.name: Claries

texts.en:
Claries is a single woman with one child who attends school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees. 

She has operated a soft drink sales business for the past two years, selling in a shop to her neighbours and passersby. Claries faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She hopes to be self-reliant in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase a freezer for storing soft drinks for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase a freezer for storing soft drinks for sale

loans.name: Glenis Graciela

texts.es: La señora Glenis Graciela Gutiérrez O. tiene 42 años y vive con sus dos hijas en el barrio Moderno de la ciudad de Barranquilla. En su casa tiene un pequeño almacén de miscelánea en el cual vende cremas, perfumes, accesorios femeninos y artículos de papelería. Ahí también funciona una peluquería en la cual ofrece servicio de corte de cabello, tintes, alicer y arreglo de uñas. Ambos negocios comenzaron en el año 2000. En su sector es ampliamente conocida por su jovialidad y buen sentido del humor, eso le ha valido el aprecio de todos sus vecinos quienes siempre recurren a ella cuando necesitan contar un problema y recargarse de energía positiva. Por la temporada decembrina, la afluencia de los clientes a la peluquería los fines de semanas se triplicó y debió contratar a una estilista a la que le paga por producción. Este es el primer crédito que la señora Glenis tramita con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y planea invertirlo en comprar artículos de papelería para atender la próxima temporada escolar que comienza en Enero. Las ventas promedio semanal de ambos negocios es de $ 600.000 COP , el margen de utilidad es del 40% y el de endeudamiento del 14%. Los planes a mediano plazo de la microempresaria son los de terminar el segundo piso de su vivienda que aún está en obra negra para organizar mejor su peluquería y su almacén. Su hija mayor se ha mostrado interesada en el oficio de estilista y Glenis ya la está entrenando para que le colabore.
texts.en:
Glenis Graciela Gutiérrez O. is 42 years old and lives with her two daughters in Moderno neighborhood, in the city of Barranquilla.  She has a small general store in her home where she sells creams, perfume, ladies' accessories and stationery.  She also runs a hairdressing salon in her home, offering hair cuts, hair coloring, hair straightening and manicures.  She started both of these businesses in the year 2000.

Glenis is well known in her neighborhood for her cheerfulness and good sense of humor.  This has meant that she is held in very high esteem by her neighbors who always come to her when they need to tell someone their problems and recharge themselves with positive energy.  During the month of December, the number of customers to Glenis' hairdressing salon at weekends tripled and she had to hire a stylist to help her.

This is Glenis' first loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo and she plans to invest it in buying stationery items for the upcoming back-to-school season that begins in January.  The average weekly sales of both of Glenis' businesses is 600,000 Colombian pesos.  Her profit margin is 40% and her debt is 14%.  Her plans in the medium term are to finish off the second floor of her home which is still being built and to better organize her hairdressing salon and her store.  Her eldest daughter has shown interest in becoming a stylist and Glenis is training her so that she can work with her.

loans.use: To buy stationery items

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel S. is from the village of Transville Villaflor. He is 29 years old. Daniel is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Daniel owns and operates a business providing Internet rental in the local community. He has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 35,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Daniel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from GDMPC. Daniel is requesting a new loan of 50,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the second loan taken out by Daniel from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand his business. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Judith

texts.en: Judith R. is from the village of Rizal, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old. Judith is married and has a school-aged child. To make a living, Judith operates a fish business. The main source of income for the business comes from buying and selling fish in the market. Judith has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2011, Judith joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Judith is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional fish to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Judith from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional fish to sell

loans.name: Fanny De Lourdes

texts.es:
La Señora. Fanny O. es socia del banco comunal Yanbal, vive por la parroquia de San Joaquín en donde su gente se dedica al comercio, cría de animales y en su mayor parte a la agricultura siendo el lugar de mayor productividad.

La Señora Fanny tiene 39 años, es casada y tiene  3 hijos de 20, 18 y 14 años de edad, su primera hija  estudia en la universidad y sus dos últimos hijos en un colegio de la ciudad. Su esposo es de profesión chofer y labora en una compañía de transportes, con el trabajo conyugal han construido su casa propia.

Doña Fanny es directora de ventas de los productos Yanbal, actividad que desempeña hace 5 años y labora de lunes a viernes con horario de oficina.

Se encuentra en el banco comunal hace 6 años,  su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en perfumes, cremas, cosméticos y bisutería. Su meta es  tener una nueva sucursal.
texts.en:
Sra. Fanny O. is a member of the Yanbal Communal Bank. She lives in the parish of San Joaquín where some of the residents engage in trade and raising animals. However, most of the people are farmers since this is a place of great bounty.

Sra. Fanny is 39 years old, married, and has three children (ages 20, 18, and 14). Her eldest daughter is at the university while the two younger children attend high school in the city. Fanny’s husband is a professional driver who works for a transportation fleet. She and her husband were able to build their own home.

Doña Fanny is a sales director of Yanbal products. She has been in this business for five years and works regular office hours Monday through Friday. Fanny has been with her Communal Bank for six years. She will invest her loan in perfumes, crèmes, cosmetics, and trinkets. Her goal is to open a new branch.

loans.use: Purchase perfumes, crèmes, cosmetics, and trinkets

loans.name: Khek

texts.en:
Khek L., 56, resides with her famiL. in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. L. and her husband sell traditional medicine, earning an income of $1 per day. Each month, the famiL. has to spend $60 on food and $44 on the other necessary expenses.
